4.27.24  9:54 pm   Your voice is so smooth, it's quite beautiful. Your drumming is always so creative and your synth playing oh my GOSHHH. Your works are nothing short of genius and I just want to say thank you, THANK YOU for posting these. I honestly don't know where I'd be without them. Your bass playing matches beautifully with the other sections. Listening to "if the world doesn't end" followed by "fly around" is like being hugged and told it'll be alright. I can't say thank you enough. Thank you for making them, thank you for posting them, THANK YOU for doing what you do. Your songs absolutely touch my soul in ways I can't describe and fill me with hope even on the worst of days. Once again: thank you.

      my goodness i seem to have stumbled into the friendly section of the website

4.27.24  12:58 pm   How did the inventors of soap come up with soap?

      it probably started with a spicy leaf someone found. then they gradually adjusted the recipe from there

4.27.24  11:18 am   lately ive been haunted by the notion that an instrumental song cant stand on its own (like it needs some other thing to go along with it).
so i tried making songs with lyrics and i suck at it, and ive been sucking at it for quite a while now.
but whenever i try to write a song w/o lyrics i think about that notion again and it ruins the whole thing.
so i think i have to either use that thought to help me make lyric songs until im good at it, or i conbince myself its not true and just make more instrumentals.
until i decide im in music limbo where i cant finish anything. do you have any thoughts on that original notion i mentioned at the start? or on the situation or whatev

      basically what you need here, is to dive head first into figuring out what really matters to you in the world, besides music. then incorporate that into music in a way that absolutely resonates with you genuinely. I too, spent most of my younger years wrapped up in only music (music music). so when it came to this point, what i did was, among other things, started freestyling text on a qwerty keyboard, from the abstract to the concrete, trying to really dig down to what means the most to me, and how i can genuinely find what i want to find, through language. after a couple of years of this, i felt more equipped with things to say and make music about, when i returned to songwriting. and i was pleasantly surprised that i was now doing it a lot differently from other songwriters, thanks to all that heck-the-out-tripping experience i'd had

4.26.24  2:36 pm   Wanting to get into music again, but dont know what instrument I want to play. None of the instruments i've looked at so far seem to appeal, any advice?

      how about your voice, in addition to something that plays chords

4.26.24  12:35 pm   How do i hear chords in songs this is hard

      it's no 'harder' than hearing english words when people are talking. it's actually quite impossible, but once you develop the ability it's effortless. what it takes is, just a long time of being exposed to the language (or music) with transcriptions to go along with it. and over a very very long period of exposure, eventually out of sheer curiosity you will get around to learning, forgetting, and re-learning, pretty much every different thing that ever happens. for each thing, (chord, word, pattern, thing that happens, whatever) i'd say on average it will take about 10 times learning/forgetting/re-learning the thing, and then you'll know it permanently. that being said, it's not definable how many 'things' there are, or what constitutes a 'thing', nor is it important for you to even know. but this process of learning still works like clockwork nonetheless, automatically, with enough exposure

4.26.24  12:19 pm   How big a square is too big a square?

      there is no limit to the size of squares

4.26.24  9:02 am   Why is it all lower case accept for the button that says ASK wich im about to press?

4.26.24  8:13 am   i feel confused between two of your most common given advice:
(1) do something bad on purpose, don't take it too seriously, and
(2) do it like a professional.

they're contradicting each other.

      those don't really contradict each other, but, more importantly, it's not clear that you've taken those from the same situation. for example, i don't recall ever giving those 2 pieces of advice to the same person in the same situation. those are likely suggestions for 2 different situations
